His case has been referred to an appeals officer who proposes to hold an oral hearing. He will be notified of the time and place of the hearing as soon as the arrangements have been made.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Supplementary Welfare Allowance Payments.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Timmins Mr. Timmins Mr. Conlon Mr. Conlon
Speaker.P: and Mr. Timmins asked the Minister for Social Welfare if he is aware of the strain that is being put on the finances of health boards through lengthy payment of supplementary welfare allowances to applicants for benefits and assistance from his Department and through the delay by his Department in processing these applications and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)
Speaker.P: A claimant for a social welfare payment of benefit or assistance who does not obtain his payment immediately may apply for a supplementary welfare allowance to meet his needs until payment commences. Every effort has been and is being made in my Department to eliminate delays but the high volume of claims, particularly unemployment claims, combined with the effects of the Government staff embargo has inevitably meant that the time taken to deal with these claims has increased and a higher number of persons may therefore have to avail themselves of the supplementary welfare allowances scheme while their claims are being decided.

This situation has created administrative difficulties for health boards both in dealing with the increased claim load and in implementing the arrangements whereby the amount of supplementary welfare allowance paid as an interim measure is recouped by my Department. There is no evidence however that the finances of health boards are being seriously affected and the recoupment arrangements are in general operating satisfactorily.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Finglas (Dublin) Workers' Benefit Entitlement.

Speaker.hpid: Miss Flaherty Miss Flaherty
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare if he will give details of the entitlements of workers at Storage Technology Products, Finglas, some of whom are currently being let go and some of whom are still at work without guarantee of salary.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)
Speaker.P: Persons who lose their employment through no fault of their own would normally qualify for unemployment benefit and pay-related supplement if they satisfy the contribution conditions.
A number of employees of the firm named by the Deputy have claimed unemployment benefit in respect of the period 12 November 1984 to 17 November 1984.
Inquiries are being made to establish whether they satisfy the conditions for receipt of benefit and when the inquiries are completed entitlement will be determined.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare the reason old age pensioners who had been in receipt of prescribed relative allowances from his Department are having their claims disallowed even though the circumstances in the particular case have not changed.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)
Speaker.P: The conditions for payment of a prescribed relative allowance provide that the person concerned must be so incapacitated as to require full time care and attention. A routine review of the continuing entitlement to the payment of the allowance is accordingly an ongoing feature of the administration of the scheme.

In the course of the review it comes to light from time to time that a prescribed relative, because of the nature of his activities, could not reasonably be in a position to provide the necessary care and attention on a full time basis. In such a situation the deciding officer may decide to terminate the allowance in fulfilment of his statutory obligations. In all such cases there is a right of appeal to an appeals officer.

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. A. Doyle Mrs. A. Doyle
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare whether all applicants for social welfare assistance payments could be entitled automatically to a full explanation on the basis of the calculation of any means assessed against them.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)
Speaker.P: Applicants for social welfare non-contributory pensions and related allowances are given formal notifications of the decision in their cases which give details of how the rate of entitlement is made up. Where means have been assessed, the amount of means is given together with the sources from which the means are obtained.

In the case of unemployment assistance applicants, the person is normally furnished with a qualification certificate setting out his total means assessments. Those who require additional information can generally have it by inquiring at their local office or by writing to the Department. Because of certain difficulties which arose in the changeover of smallholders from a notional to a factual method of means assessment, arrangements were made earlier this year to have all such small holders informed of the gross income assessed and the gross expenditure figures from which the net income is derived which is the basis of the means assessed against them.

The provision of more detailed information would, because of staffing constraints arising from Government policy in relation to the reduction of numbers in the public service, create serious problems. Staff are finding it difficult to cope with increasing workloads and because of the very large numbers involved, the preparation of additional information in each case could only result, in present circumstances, in further delays in the processing of claims.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. McEllistrim Mr. McEllistrim
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare if he will review the social welfare conditions of CIE personnel concerning stamp contributions paid prior to 1953 for superannuation purposes.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)
Speaker.P: The statutory contributions conditions for qualification for old age contributory pension and retirement pensions provide that the person must
(i) have contributions paid at an appropriate rate in respect of at least 156 weeks of insurable employment since his entry into insurance, and

(ii) for retirement pension, have a yearly average of at least 24 contributions or, for old age contributory pension, have a yearly average of at least 20 contributions. This average is calculated over the period from January 1953 or year of entry into insurance, if later, to the end of the contribution year preceding the one in which pension age is reached.

Salaried staff who are covered by CIE's superannuation scheme pay PRSI contributions at a modified rate to provide cover for the widows' and orphans' pension schemes. Such contributions are not reckonable for either old age contributory pension or retirement pension.
There are no proposals at present to change the existing arrangements in these matters.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. McCarthy Dr. McCarthy
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare the steps which will be taken by his Department to improve conditions at Clonmel employment exchange, as due to the huge number of people unemployed in the town, many are forced to queue and wait outside in the rain.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)
Speaker.P: The employment exchange premises in Clonmel are considered to be adequate to cater for the number of unemployed persons attending there at present. The queueing which is occurring on pay days could be avoided if claimants adhered to their allotted signing times. I am, however, having the existing signing and pay arrangements reviewed with a view to seeing what can be done to improve matters.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Durkan Mr. Durkan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare when unemployment assistance will be paid to a person (details supplied) in County Kildare having regard to the hardship currently experienced by this applicant who has a wife and a large family.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)
Speaker.P: The person concerned was assessed with means of £19.20 weekly derived from the profit from land. He is accordingly entitled to unemployment assistance at £69.50 weekly being the appropriate rate £88.70 less £19.20 means. All arrears due less advances of supplementary welfare allowance were paid on 6 December 1984 and further weekly payments will be made as they become due.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Social Welfare Benefits Double-Payment.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. McCarthy Dr. McCarthy
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare the reasons he has excluded unemployed persons and their dependants from the double-payment of social welfare benefits for Christmas; and whether it is his intention to reverse this decision so as to alleviate the hardship presently being experienced by the families involved.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)
Speaker.P: As announced on 25 October last the Government decided that a double-payment would be made for Christmas to recipients of the following social welfare payments:
old age, retirement, blind, invalidity and occupational injury pensions and payments for widows and orphans, deserted wives, unmarried mothers, single women and prisoner's wives.
The double payment also applies to recipients of the following health allowances:

MainHeading.P: disabled persons maintenance allowance, infectious diseases maintenance allowance, blind welfare allowance and domiciliary care allowance for handicapped children.

These are the same categories who benefited from a Christmas double-payment in each of the last four years 1980, 1981, 1982 and 1983. In all some 414,000 persons benefit from the extra payment at a cost to the Exchequer of some £20 million.

As in previous years no provision was made in the original Social Welfare Estimate for the double-payment at Christmas. The necessary provision had therefore to be found within the Government's overall spending targets for 1984 and the maximum amount that was available was some £20 million. It would not be possible to dispense it strictly on the basis of financial need without having an across the board means test for all recipients. It was necessary therefore to choose in terms of broad categories of recipients and the Government decided to give the double-payment to those who benefited in past years i.e. pensioners and those in receipt of equivalent payments.

The extra cost of giving a double payment to receipients of unemployment benefit and assistance would be about £11 million. Those on long term unemployment assistance had received in October 1983 a special 5 per cent increase in their payments and in July of this year a further 1 per cent increase above the general level of increase for social welfare beneficiaries. Those special increases are equivalent to an extra weeks payments to those on long term unemployment assistance. As regards unemployment benefit pay-related benefit in many cases provides a high overall level of payment.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Hyland Mr. Hyland
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare if his Department will now approve an unemployment assistance appeal from a person (details supplied) in County Laois.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)
Speaker.P: The unemployment assistance claim of the person concerned was disallowed on the grounds that he failed to disclose his means to the social welfare officer. He appealed against the disallowance on 24 April 1984 but due to misfiling his case was not dealt with until 14 August 1984 when the case was returned to the social welfare officer to afford the applicant a further opportunity to cooperate. Inquiries are still being made and when they are completed his entitlement to unemployment assistance will be reviewed accordingly. He is at present in receipt of supplementary welfare allowance pending the outcome of his unemployment assistance claim.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Galway Social Welfare Payments.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare the amount of unemployment assistance and unemployment benefit paid in the last week of November 1984, to those registered at Galway city employment exchange.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)
Speaker.P: The amount of unemployment benefit (including pay-related benefit) paid to persons registered as unemployed at Galway city exchange during week ended 30 November 1984 was £100,955. The amount of unemployment assistance paid (including payments to small holders) during that week was £228,866.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare the reasons injury benefit payments, etc. have not been paid to a person (details supplied) in County Galway, despite the fact that medical certificates have been posted weekly; if he will now direct his Department to make immediate payments, both weekly and arrears; the amounts of both; the date on which they will be paid; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)
Speaker.P: The person concerned claimed injury benefit from 20 August 1984 in respect of an incapacity resulting from an alleged accident at work on 19 January 1984.
Pending examination of the claim he was allowed disability benefit on an interim basis from 24 August 1984 the fourth day of certified incapacity.

There was a delay in payment in respect of the period 27 August to 4 October due to difficulties in clarifying the amount of supplementary welfare allowance advanced by the Western Health Board which was recoverable from the benefit due. Disability benefit amounting to £546.25 in respect of the period from 27 August to 4 October was withheld and refunded to the health board.

Disability benefit has been paid regularly on receipt of medical certificates in respect of the period since 5 October. A deduction of £4.91 a week is being made from his benefit of £104.75 leaving a balance in payment of £99.84 a week. A balance of supplementary welfare allowance advanced is being recovered by means of the deductions.
Injury benefit is statutorily confined to a maximum period of 26 weeks from the date of the accident.
The claim to injury benefit was therefore rejected on the grounds that the period of certified incapacity (from 20 August) was outside the injury benefit period, which ended on 18 July.
If he considers that he suffered any disablement resulting from the accident it is open to him to claim disablement benefit.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - British Non-Payment of Premium.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Walsh Mr. J. Walsh
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture the steps he proposes to take to redress the serious problem caused by the non-payment of variable premium on vac-pac exports over 5 per cent to the British market.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. MacSharry Mr. MacSharry
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture the situation in relation to the negotiations with the UK on the refusal of Britain to pay the beef variable premium on any vacuum packed beef over 5 per cent of eligible imports from Ireland; and if it is true that the British rejection of the grading standards of another member state is in breach of Community protocol.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 278 and 279 together. This matter is the subject of ongoing discussions with the UK authorities and the Deputies can be assured that I will take every possible step open to me to ensure that the problem is satisfactorily resolved as quickly as possible.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - National Milk Purchasing Agency.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kitt Mr. Kitt
Speaker.P: asked the Minister if a joint purchasing agency will be established to deal with the effects of the super-levy.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kitt Mr. Kitt
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture his plans for establishing a national milk purchasing agency.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture if he will make a statement on the milk levy situation and whether or not he proposes to operate a national milk purchasing agency, the reasons for the delay in making a decision as regards this agency and if he will make a statement on the future of dairying in this country.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 281, 282 and 283 together. A National Milk Purchasing Agency was in fact established by the industry in June but its operation is subject to the approval of the EC Commission. My Department requested an early decision from the Commission but while this has not yet been received it is expected very shortly.

MainHeading.P: As regards the future of dairying in Ireland, the concession that I negotiated allows producers the right to expand this year at close to our normal rate of increase with the possibility of further increases in future years. On the marketing side, I would expect some improvements as the impact of the levy is felt in other member states and as the effects of the international recession decline. It is, of course, now more important than ever that the industry moves away from intervention products towards high added-value consumer products, and I hope that this trend will be accelerated in the future.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture the reasons for accepting both a milk super-levy and an increase in the co-responsibility levy in the Brussels negotiations of 1984 and if he will make a statement on these matters.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: The decisions to increase the co-responsibility levy on milk and to introduce a quota system in the Community milk sector were taken by the Council of Agriculture Ministers during the farm price negotiations earlier this year. They were part of a general package deal with rising expenditure and structural surpluses on a number of agricultural markets.

In the milk sector failure to contain production would in a short period have threatened the viability of the whole market system with very serious consequences for dairy farmers throughout the Community. The super-levy system was seen as the most effective way of tackling the problem. The Deputy will be aware that the agreement eventually reached took special account of Ireland's particular situation with regard to dairying. The general co-responsibility levy was increased to help offset the rising budgetary costs of the milk policy and, in particular, to take account of the fact that the quotas fixed for 1984-85 were generally higher than those for future years.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kitt Mr. Kitt
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture if he envisages any changes in the operations of the co-responsibility levy, in view of the introduction of the super-levy and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: There are no changes envisaged in the operation of the co-responsibility levy, as a result of the introduction of the super-levy.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Walsh Mr. J. Walsh
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture if, as an encouragement to new product development, he will seek a derogation from the milk super-levy for milk converted into new milk-based foods which will not contribute to the traditional milk products surplus; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: The present EC regulations governing the milk super-levy do not permit such a derogation and there is no prospect of any such derogation being agreed in the foreseeable future. Product diversification is primarily a matter for the milk processing industry and I would hope that the industry would avail itself fully of the investment aid towards diversification which is available from the Industrial Development Authority and in certain circumstances from the guidance section of FEOGA as well.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Griffin Mr. Griffin
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture the steps his Department are taking to promote the school milk scheme to its full potential.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: The promotion of the scheme is primarily a matter for the dairies in co-operation with the schools. In an effort to have the scheme more widely used my Department's officials have met with the various interests involved — the dairies, the National Dairies' Association, the National Dairy Council and representatives of the teachers unions. As a result of these meetings an intensive publicity campaign was launched recently by the National Dairy Council. Individual dairies have also undertaken to increase their effort to promote the scheme. It is understood that there has been some increase in consumption recently and I am hopeful that this publicity drive will have the desired effect.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture if he will negotiate an increase in both A and B surgar quotas for the severely disadvantaged western area from the EC authorities and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: Sugar quotas are allocated nationally and not to specific areas. I will of course be endeavouring to secure the most favourable arrangements possible for the Irish industry when negotiations commence.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kitt Mr. Kitt
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture when the catchment areas and acreage of sugar beet will be decided on for each sugar factory.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: These are matters for the Sugar Company to decide. I understand that any such decisions will be taken in good time for the signing of the 1985 beet contracts.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kitt Mr. Kitt
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture when a subvention will be paid to Tuam sugar factory, Co Galway.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: A subvention to the Tuam sugar factory would be incompatible with the provisions of the EC Treaty which deal with State aids.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Pigs and Bacon Commission.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. H. Byrne Mr. H. Byrne Mr. J. Walsh Mr. J. Walsh Mr. Noonan (Limerick West) Mr. Noonan (Limerick West)
Speaker.P: (Limerick West), Mr. J. Walsh and Mr. H. Byrne asked the Minister for Agriculture in view of the unrest in the pig industry as a result of a statement issued by the Pigs and Bacon Commission that they intend to wind up their operation because of inadequate funding, if he will take the necessary action to ensure the survival of this body; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. MacSharry Mr. MacSharry
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture in view of the imminent winding up of the Pigs and Bacon Commission, the measures, if any, planned by him to ensure that export outlets continue to be available to pig producers; and if, given that the pig sector is efficiently organised at production level, he considers it a matter of urgency to take measures to ensure that pig exports are not jeopardised.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 292 and 293 together. The decision taken by the industry-run private company, Pigs and Bacon Commission Limited (PBC Ltd) to wind down its operations is one which, naturally, I regret. However, I appreciate the difficulties that it encountered in obtaining adequate financing from the industry. The fact that certain curers were unwilling to support its centralised exporting activities added to the company's difficulties.

Since the announcement of PBC Ltd's decision, meetings have been held with both curer and producer representatives to discuss among other things the implications for the export trade in pigmeat. The industry is well aware of my belief that centralised exporting is in the best interests of the pigmeat sector since otherwise the volume of exports is likely to decline. In the final analysis, however, the industry must decide for itself what export arrangements will suit it best and it is not possible to impose any particular arrangement on it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture if he has any plans for the introduction of a carcase classification scheme for the lamb trade, and if he will make a statement on the grading and marketing of lambs in this country at present.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: A system of grading lamb carcases was introduced in 1978 to assist the development of exports to France and it has been continued since then as an aid to identifying quality carcases for export. The question of a lamb classification scheme has been discussed with representatives of producers and exporters on a number of occasions but no final conclusions have been reached. Further discussions have been arranged for early next month. My Department would be prepared to assist the industry in operating a scheme but agreement would have to be reached on meeting the cost.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Flour Imports.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture if he is aware of the serious threat to the Irish flour milling industry as a result of the dumping of imported flour in this country, the action he proposes to take thereon to protect Irish jobs and if he will make a statement on the entire situation.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: I am, of course, aware that flour imports from the UK have been causing difficulties for the flourmilling industry here. Apart from the fact that EC rules prohibit the imposition of restrictions on imports from other member states, such a course would not be in our interest, as a major exporter of agricultural products.

MainHeading.P: My Department has brought the difficulties caused by the flour imports to the notice of the EC Commission and the UK authorities but again, because of EC rules, the action open to those authorities is limited. Essentially what is required is that Irish bakers and other flour users should be aware of the consequences for the economy and for employment generally, arising from the use of imported flour. I have stressed this aspect in the course of my dealings with all interested parties. The flour milling industry has recently launched a campaign to encourage the use of Irish made flour by bakers and this campaign deserves the fullest possible support.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. McEllistrim Mr. McEllistrim
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture if he proposes to waive the brucellosis test on cows that are sold at marts and sent directly to the factory for slaughter and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: Any change on the lines proposed by the Deputy would be contrary to Community law. In any event, it would be foolhardy at this critical stage of the brucellosis eradication campaign to make any such change when success is clearly in prospect.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kelly Mr. Kelly
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture the Government's intentions in regard to the prohibition of hare coursing.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: I would refer the Deputy to my reply on 1 March 1984 to previous questions on this matter, when I indicated that I was looking into the whole question of coursing. In the interim, I have received submissions from many interested parties and these are currently being examined.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture if he has had consultations with the Irish Transport and General Workers Union who represent the artificial insemination service personnel with regard to introducing a DIYAI service, and if so when these consultations were held having regard to a written assurance given to the union by one of his predecessors and if he will indicate his intentions with regard to any changes he is considering in the service.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: Two meetings between the unions involved in the AI service, including the ITGWU, and officials of my Department have taken place on 28 September and 5 December 1984. A further meeting will take place in the near future. The conditions of the DIYAI service have now been finalised and circulated to the interests concerned.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Leonard Mr. J. Leonard
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture if he is aware of the trend in artificial insemination from milk to beef breeds and the serious implication it could have in future years in milk production and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: While fluctuations occur in the proportions of dairy and beef breed inseminations, the trend this year has been a fairly pronounced decline in dairy breed inseminations. If this trend were to continue in future years it would, of course, have implications for dairy herd replacement and consequently for milk production. However, it will be necessary to observe the actual pattern of inseminations over the next few years.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture if he is satisfied with the quality of compound fertilisers being manufactured throughout the country, the number of inspectors from his Department who have carried out tests on various fertilisers over the past year, the results of these tests and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Leonard Mr. J. Leonard
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture if, in view of the deep concern expressed recently regarding fertiliser quality, he is satisfied that there is adequate monitoring of quality by his Department.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 300 and 301 together. In the fertiliser year ended 30 June 1984, 360 samples were taken by eight authorised officers and analysed in the State Laboratory. Seventy-three of the samples were found to be at variance with the statutory standards. Discussions have taken place on the subject with the IFA and fertiliser manufacturers. The position regarding composition, sampling and analysis is being examined by my Department in consultation with the State Laboratory and further discussions with the producer and trade interests are envisaged.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture the total amount of unclaimed moneys available from the EC authorities for a lime subsidy in 1984, if he will make special application for these moneys and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: The EC lime subsidy scheme was terminated on 30 April 1984. There were no EC funds assigned for the operation of a scheme after that date.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Leonard Mr. J. Leonard
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture the action he proposes to take to encourage a higher level of usage of lime and fertiliser.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: The operation of the lime subsidy scheme during the three year period up to April 1984 brought lime sales to the highest level for many years. In addition the levels of application of nitrogen, phosphorous and potash increased steadily over the last three years. ACOT, of course will continue to advise farmers on appropriate lime and fertiliser application programmes.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Public Service Recruitment Embargo.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kirk Mr. Kirk
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture if he will consider exempting ACOT Advisory Service from the public service recruitment embargo.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kirk Mr. Kirk
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture if he will consider exempting An Foras Talúntais from the public service recruitment embargo.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Monaghan Agricultural Training.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Leonard Mr. J. Leonard
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture the reason an allocation was made to County Monaghan for agricultural training in the programme for western development.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: Specific allocations for capital works in agricultural training are a matter for ACOT.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Home Production of Cereals.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Leonard Mr. J. Leonard
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture if he noted a comment made by the director of the Agricultural Institute on the need for replacement of imported animal feed products by home grown materials and if so, the action he proposes to take to help in righting the position.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: On several occasions I have stressed the need for increasing home production of cereals and for replacing imported feed by our own native grain. Ample supplies of high quality home-produced feed grain are in fact currently available at reasonable prices and as much as possible of this grain should be included in livestock rations. While decisions as to the ingredients included in rations are essentially a matter for feed manufacturers and their customers, I see no reason why they should not incorporate more home-produced grain in the rations.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture if he will immediately allocate a section of his Department to organise the marketing of Irish vegetables and if he will make a detailed statement on the entire vegetable production and marketing situation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kirk Mr. Kirk
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture the plans he has for the development of the horticultural industry.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 311 and 312 together. The overall acreage of vegetables for sale on the fresh market has increased steadily in recent years but certain individual crops, notably early tomatoes and onions, have declined in the face of competition from imports. There is scope for recovery in these areas and also for further expansion of other crops such as carrots and cauliflowers to meet the increasing market demand over a longer season. In the industry as a whole there is an urgent need for greater organisation to meet modern market conditions with emphasis on providing high-quality produce in continuous supply over an extended season. This would enable the industry to meet the increasing pressure of competition from imports and to develop its full potential.

The question of organising the marketing of vegetables is primarily a matter for the industry itself but a number of initiatives in this direction are being taken by the sections of my Department which deal with horticultural matters. For example, financial aid is being provided towards the employment of a market coordinator by the glasshouse industry. Aid is also available towards the formation of producer groups in the vegetable sector. The horticultural development group is advising on the development prospects, and the inter-departmental committee on food imports has pinpointed the import substitution possibilities for vegetables. I would like to see the horticultural industry responding with a greater degree of urgency to the opportunities presented by these various measures.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Import Substitution.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Leonard Mr. J. Leonard
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture the progress which has been made in the matter of import substitution of fruit and vegetables.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kirk Mr. Kirk
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture the steps he is taking to encourage the import substitution of vegetables, potatoes and fruit.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 316 and 317 together.

MainHeading.P: Imports of fresh vegetables of the type grown in this country dropped from 124,000 tonnes in 1982 to 69,000 in 1983, the main reduction being in potatoes. Efforts are being continued by my Department, An Foras Talúntais and An Comhairle Oiliúna Talmhaíochta (ACOT) in conjunction with the growers' organisations to seek ways of further reducing imports by the application of new production technology and the improvement of marketing arrangements. Imports of apples, the main fruit grown in this country, continue to increase. Progress in this area will be slower as it would require the plantation of new orchards which take some years to reach commercial production.

The precise opportunities for import substitution have been identified in the report of the interdepartmental committee on food imports. The framework for progress exists in the financial inducements provided by my Department such as the aid towards the formation of a national co-operative for potatoes; aid for market co-ordination for glasshouse crops, and aid for setting up producer groups in the general fruit and vegetable sectors. The scope for progress and expansion exists and it is a matter for growers and other interests in the industry to exploit these opportunities and avail of the supports so as to reduce unnecessary imports.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture in view of the National Plan's emphasis on increasing agricultural output through land improvement, and in view of the Taoiseach's and his own publicly stated opinions that the western drainage scheme is an outstanding success, if he envisages lifting the embargo in force since last February on all new applications under the scheme, thereby ensuring that the drainage necessary to ensure increased output and prudent management of our natural resources will take place.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions 326 to 338, inclusive, together.

MainHeading.P: Under the western drainage scheme the area which may be the subject of field drainage is limited by the EC to 150,000 hectares. Up to a recent date approval had issued for 162,000 hectares, and there were some 10,000 applications on hands from persons interested in carrying out field drainage under the measure. Making due allowance for projects which for various reasons would not be carried out, it had been estimated that applications received up to 30 September 1981 would account for the full area allowed. However, by not claiming reimbursement from the EC for certain less-intensive joint works, (except in conjunction with a claim for field drainage), it will be possible to increase the amount of field drainage which can be carried out under the EC measures, and thus cater for applications received up to about the end of 1981. Processing of these applications will commence without delay and they will arise for payment in 1986 and 1987. This course has become possible as a result of the additional funds made available under the national plan.

The rate of grant under the western drainage scheme is 70 per cent of the approved cost subject to a maximum grant of £560 per hectare. Applications under the scheme are dealt with strictly in order of receipt and this will continue. When approval is issued for a drainage project a time limit is imposed for the completion of the work, and failure to meet the deadline can result in cancellation of the approval and loss of grant-aid. Such time limits will continue to be enforced. There is no question of moneys available from the EC under the scheme remaining unclaimed. In accordance with normal procedure claims are forwarded to the Commission each year in respect of sums disbursed by the State under the scheme. An examination is being made of the options available for dealing with outstanding applications which cannot be catered for within the extension of the scheme now proposed. When a decision is reached on this and on the matter of future drainage in the west, an announcement will be made. As regards arterial drainage, this is a matter for the Office of Public Works. The Corrib-Mask-Robe, the Boyle and the Bonet catchments are included in the western drainage scheme and there are no proposals at present to include further catchments.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Kildare Garda Stations.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Durkan Mr. Durkan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he will examine the possibility of creating a new Garda sub-division in County Kildare with particular reference to north Kildare where the increased population in the towns of Leixlip, Celbridge and Maynooth warrant such a measure and where such action could have a considerable impact on the increase in crime in the area; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Durkan Mr. Durkan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he has reconsidered the possibility of providing a Garda station in Leixlip, County Kildare, with a view to combating drug trafficking and other crimes, taking into account the rapidly expanding population; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): I propose to take Questions Nos. 387 and 388 together.

There are no proposals at present for the creation of a new Garda district, or sub-division, in County Kildare or for the establishment of a Garda station at Leixlip but the police needs of the developing areas in the county are being kept under regular review by the Garda authorities.

As I indicated in my reply to Question No. 78 on 14 December 1983, one of the difficulties about establishing a new Garda district is the need for additional manpower on indoor duty at the expense of outdoor operational duty. There is a similar difficulty about the establishment of a new Garda station. Accordingly, before embarking on structural changes or establishing a new station in any area, it is necessary to look at the possibility of providing an improved Garda service for that area by the allocation of additional manpower and other resources within the existing organisational arrangements.

Since the beginning of this year, one extra Garda has been allocated to each of the stations at Celbridge and Maynooth and new communications equipment has been installed at both centres as part of the new national radio network. Final testing of the equipment is at present in progress and the new network is expected to be in operation early in the new year. The current Garda strength at Lucan is 47 as compared with 37 at the end of 1981 and, in addition, part of the area formerly served from the station is now served from the station at Ronanstown which opened in January last.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): The amount of overtime worked by prison officers has fallen by an average of three hours per officer per week since 1982. The prison service is subject to the terms of the Government embargo on the filling of posts. Some recruitment will, however, be taking place and, when it does, the question of the allocation of additional officers to Mountjoy Prison will be considered.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Circuit Court Staff.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he is aware of the staff shortages in various Circuit Court offices throughout the country, the number of staff who have retired from Circuit Court offices since 1980, the numbers who replaced them, if he is aware that Circuit Court decisions are not being implemented as a result of these staff shortages, if he will now ensure that adequate staff are available to these offices to ensure implementation of court decisions, and if he will make a statement on the situation.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): The total number of staff in Circuit Court offices who have retired or resigned since 1 January 1980 is 79. Of these 63 have been replaced to date. Fifteen posts cannot be filled under the terms of the Government's policy limiting staff numbers in the Civil Service.

The deployment of staff in a Circuit Court office is a matter for the county registrar concerned. I am informed that first priority is given to servicing the sittings of the court and, after that, recording the decisions reached. I am not aware that staff shortages have resulted in any serious delays in the working of the courts in so far as these functions are concerned.

MainHeading.P: I am aware, however, that there are delays in some offices in the enforcement of execution orders and of revenue certificates. As a contribution to the solution of this problem sanction has been obtained on an exceptional basis for the filling of six court messenger posts. Three of these became vacant as a result of retirements or resignations and are posts which, in the normal way, could not be filled. The other three are new posts. Of the six, three have already been filled and arrangements are in hand for the filling of three more. I am keeping the position under review.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Louth Policing Arrangements.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Farrelly Mr. Farrelly
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice the reason there were no gardaí on duty in Ardee town, County Louth, on Saturday, 13 October 1984, when a fatal incident took place; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kirk Mr. Kirk
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he will arrange to have Garda night patrols in Ardee town, County Louth.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): I propose to take Questions Nos. 397 and 398 together.

The precise arrangements for the policing of individual areas are a matter for the Garda authorities. They report that night patrols are operated in Ardee by the local station party to the maximum extent possible, having regard to available resources and other demands on Garda services, and that the area is covered from the district headquarters at Navan outside the hours when the local members are on patrol.

I am informed by the Garda authorities that the fatal incident referred to in Question No. 397 took place shortly after 3 a.m. at a time when local gardaí were not on duty but that the local sergeant was on the scene very quickly and three other members of the Ardee station party arrived a short time later.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. O'Leary Mr. J. O'Leary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he is aware of the grave concern among the public and the legal profession at the long delays on the part of the Land Registry in completing dealings, sending out Land Registry maps to solicitors, and in having applications for registration of titles completed; if he is satisfied that there is adequate staff to cope with the increasing number of applications for maps, and registration of titles; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): I am aware that there has been some general deterioration in regard to the time taken to deal with applications in the Land Registry over the last few years but I would not agree that the position is such as would justify grave concern. The delay in dealing with some categories of cases is not significant.

The Deputy will be aware that successive Governments since 1981 have found it necessary, because of the financial situation, to adopt a policy of reducing staff numbers in the Civil Service — a policy which manifests itself as an embargo on filling certain vacancies. The effect on the Land Registry is that the current authorised staffing of the registry is approximately 14 per cent lower than the authorised level prior to the introduction of the embargo. In addition, the most recent estimate of the volume of work being dealt with by the registry shows an increase of 9 per cent approximately, over the 1980 level, the year of reference to which the staffing level was fixed. Everything possible is being done by the registry to speed up the processing of applications within the staffing constraints involved in the general policy on Civil Service numbers.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Woods Dr. Woods
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he will consider setting up pilot studies using “police points” or “police clinics” in areas with a high crime rate; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Woods Dr. Woods
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he will consider establishing “police points” or “police clinics” in flat complexes or other community areas which are removed from the local police station.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): I propose to take Questions Nos. 403 and 404 together. I am aware that the terms “police points” or “police clinics” have been used to describe experiments that have been carried out in some other countries whereby police officers are deployed at locations other than police stations within local communities.

Schemes of this nature have some advantages but they require careful evaluation in the light of local circumstances to determine whether they are the best way of using available resources. Some years ago in fact the idea was considered here but it was not thought appropriate then having regard to prevailing circumstances. However, in the context of other developments now under consideration relating to community policing and the introduction of improved radio communications within the force the matter will be further considered.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): I propose to take Questions Nos. 405 and 406 together. The Garda code is an internal confidential Garda document issued for the guidance of members of the force and the arrangements for updating it are a matter for the Garda authorities.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. L.T. Cosgrave Mr. L.T. Cosgrave
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice the research and investigations carried out which apparently indicate that it would be desirable to have longer licensing hours; if he intends to publish the reports of the research carried out; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): I propose to take Questions Nos 407 and 408 together. The decision to extend the opening hours of licensed premises in the summer months was taken in the context of the Government's intention to remove obstacles to the development of the tourist trade. MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Garda Síochána Civilian Posts.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Woods Dr. Woods
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice the number of civilians working in the Garda Síochána in the most recent month for which figures are available; the number of civilian posts which were not filled because of the embargo within the public service; and if he will outline his policy for the next 12 months in relation to the use of civilians within the Garda Síochána.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Woods Dr. Woods
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice the effect the present embargo on recruitment of staff in the Civil Service is having on the Garda Síochána, particularly in relation to the number of gardaí who are at present doing desk jobs in the various depots; and if they could be released from this work if the embargo is lifted.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): I propose to take Questions Nos. 412 and 413 together.

As at 1 December 1984 there were 597 civilians attached to the Garda Síochána of which 440 were employed on clerical duties and 157 in industrial-related and other similar type posts. Thirty six clerical posts cannot be filled by civilians due to the embargoes on the filling of Civil Service vacancies and the duties involved are being carried out by members of the force.

It is my intention to continue the present policy of appointing civilians to clerical posts in Garda offices to the maximum extent practicable thereby releasing as many gardaí as possible for operational police duties. However, as the Deputies will no doubt appreciate, this policy cannot be considered in isolation from overall Government policy in relation to staffing in the public service and must take account of the general restrictions on public service recruitment.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Treatment of Drug Addicts.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Woods Dr. Woods
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice the plans he has to provide for the treatment of drug addicts who have been confined to prison.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): It would be wrong to think that it is feasible for the prison medical officers or for prison personnel to provide elaborate therapy calculated to cure addicted prisoners of their addiction. Even if pressure on the accommodation in the closed prisons were not a problem, treatment techniques, which rely very largely on the commitment of the person concerned to overcome the addiction, cannot easily be applied in the prison setting. On the other hand, a proportion of the persons treated for drug addiction in the available clinics and centres, including Coolmine Lodge and its sister centre, St. Martha's, is, in fact, composed of persons released from the prisons temporarily for the purpose of receiving treatment.

Where, for one reason or another, a prisoner cannot be referred for treatment to one of the clinics or centres, the prison medical officer provides whatever help he can to enable the prisoner to cope with the enforced withdrawal from the use of the drug to which he had become addicted. In addition group therapy sessions are conducted in the prisons where practicable. In due course, the courts will be able to commit suitable offenders direct to a custodial treatment centre designated by the Minister for Health under section 28 of the Misuse of Drugs Act, 1977, rather than to a prison.

A study entitled “Drug Abuse in the Dublin Committal Prisons” by officers of my Department, which was published in 1983, is available in the Library. It contains useful information on various aspects of the matter, including the problems connected with treatment.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Termination of Ground Rents.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Woods Dr. Woods
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice the plans he has to bring about the termination of the present system of ground rent on domestic dwellings.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): The Landlord and Tenant (Ground Rents) Act, 1978, effectively prevented the creation of new ground rents on dwelling houses and this was followed by a second Act in the same year (the Landlord and Tenant (Ground Rents) (No. 2), Act) which had the declared purpose of providing a low cost purchase scheme which would lead to the termination of existing ground rents. The No. 2 Act which had a life of five years to 31 July 1982 was extended, subject to increased fees, for a further year in 1982. Earlier this year I promoted legislation which was enacted by the Oireachtas and which extended the life of the special purchase scheme for a further three years up to 31 July 1987, again with increased fees. The enactment of that recent legislation represents the policy of the Government in this matter.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Drug Abuse in Prisons.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Woods Dr. Woods
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice the measures he proposes to take to prevent the illegal passage of drugs to prisoners in Mountjoy Prison and in St. Patrick's Institution.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): I am satisfied that the Governors of all the prisons and places of detention are fully aware of the likelihood that some of those in their custody have been drug abusers in the community and would continue to abuse drugs in custody if they could.

Various precautions are already being taken and Governors are free to add to them. On the other hand neither I nor the prison authorities would wish to add unduly to the restrictions that prisoners and detainees are subject to in order to make absolutely sure that a few drug abusers do not come into possession of drugs while they are in custody. Thus, for example, it is not proposed to introduce a barrier between all prisoners and detainees and their visitors though such a barrier is provided in Mountjoy Prison in the case of prisoners known to be drug abusers.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he is aware of the deep concern that exists among the people of Donnycarney about the level of crime and vandalism and the inadequacy of Garda patrol strength and activity in the area; and if he will take urgent measures to improve the situation.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): The precise arrangements for the policing of individual areas are a matter for the Garda authorities and the allocation of manpower between patrol duty and other duties is a matter for the local Garda officers having regard to available resources, local circumstances, other demands on Garda services and the time of day or night.

I am informed by the Garda authorities that they are aware of the concern of residents of Donnycarney about incidents of crime and vandalism in the area and that Garda officers at Raheny have had a meeting with local residents about the matter. I understand that malicious damage to a local school gave rise to particular concern and that eight young boys — roughly in the ten to 12 year old age bracket — who were involved in that incident are being dealt with under the juvenile liaison officer scheme which provides for an alternative to prosecution for young offenders subject to certain conditions.

As regards measures to deal with the incidence of crime in the Donnycarney area, I am informed by the Garda authorities that special anti-vandalism patrols have been introduced and that the area is receiving regular attention from mobile patrols operating from both Clontarf and Raheny stations. These measures will be kept under review by the local Garda officers so as to ensure that resources are being deployed to best advantage in combating crime and vandalism in the area.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice the number of barring orders issued in (a) District Courts; and (b) Circuit Courts in the year ending July 1984.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Flynn Mr. Flynn
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice the progress made towards the streamlining and improving of services being provided by the Land Registry.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerich East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerich East): Over recent years various measures have been introduced to improve the service provided by the registry. These include: the division of the work into geographical groups; a new system of producing copy maps with copy folio attached; computerisation of folios; improvement of work practices particularly in public offices; introduction of word processing; planned structural alterations in the Chancery Street building; improve staff training, including facilities to acquire legal qualifications; the holding of seminars for solicitors.

Although delays continue to occur in the registry because of public service restrictions on staffing, the overall position has much improved because of the measures taken and in some areas the delays have been reduced to negligible proportions as compared with the position obtaining some years ago.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - DPP Decisions.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Dea Mr. O'Dea
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he will now consider introducing legislation which would oblige the Director of Public Prosecutions to state reasons for which he arrives at a decision to prosecute or not to prosecute in the type of case relating to a person (details supplied).

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): The answer is “no” While I have no statutory or other responsibility in relation to the office of the Director of Public Prosecutions, I am aware that the general refusal of the director to give, publicly, reasons for decisions not to prosecute is not based on any reluctance to be accountable for his decisions but on the fact that a policy of giving reasons would inevitably, in very many cases, mean serious damage to the reputation of individuals. The same attitude was adopted over the years by successive Attorneys General who, before the appointment of the director, discharged the functions now discharged by him.

MainHeading.P: The text of the question, however, refers to a particular “type of case”. If the suggestion is that reasons should be given in and only in rare cases where there are very exceptional circumstances the position may be somewhat different. I am aware that the director is in principle prepared to consider giving reasons in such very exceptional cases if some satisfactory means can be found of defining or otherwise categorising them so that the giving of reasons in those cases and the refusal of reasons in other cases would not lead to inferences being drawn in those other cases that could be as indefensibly damaging to individuals as the general giving of reasons would be. I am informed that the question whether something could be done to isolate and identify such very exceptional cases has been under consideration but that no satisfactory means or formula has yet been found.

In the meantime, it appears to me that any issues of public interest that might have been raised by the case referred to in the question have effectively been resolved by the fact that, since the question was first put on the Order Paper, certain details of the evidence of what led up to the incident have been published in a newspaper. While it is not for me, as Minister for Justice, to defend or explain the director's decision, it seems to me that anybody who has read that newspaper report and who is familiar with what is legally required to sustain a charge of manslaughter (not to mention murder) would need no further explanation.

The question also refers to decisions to prosecute. Except in circumstances where it is later decided not to proceed — in which case the comments already made apply — a decision to prosecute is explained by the presentation of the evidence in court.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. McGahon Mr. McGahon
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice the cost of the Garda Síochána protection at the recent Sinn Féin conference; and the number of gardaí used for this operation.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): It is contrary to long established practice to disclose information about the numbers of gardaí involved in any policing operation or to give information as to cost which could be used to quantify the number of personnel involved. I can say, however, that, so far as the occasion referred to in the question is concerned — in which, incidentally, the Garda role was essentially concerned with normal policing rather than protection — it was necessary to employ a number of gardaí on overtime and the estimated cost of this, over and above the cost of normal salaries and allowances, was £1,200.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Dublin Policing Requirements.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Woods Mr. Woods
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice when the review of the policing requirements of the Dublin Metropolitan Area will be completed; and the progress made to date.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): I take it that the Deputy is referring to the review of policing requirements in the Dublin Metropolitan Area which was carried out by a team consisting of representatives from the Garda Síochána and from the Operations Research Section of the Department of the Public Service. This team has produced a report containing a number of recommendations of which some have been implemented and others are being implemented or are still under consideration.

I want again to make a point that has already been made about reports of this nature. This report is a confidential document prepared to assist those with responsibility for the management of the Garda Síochána and, in accordance with normal practice, I do not propose to publish its contents.

MainHeading.P: I can say, however, that the recommendations made in the report have been taken into account, for example in the introduction of a new rostering system designed to have extra gardaí on duty at times when there is greatest need for their services and in the assignment to particular stations of extra Garda strength as it becomes available.

I want also to make the point that reviewing the system of policing in the Dublin Metropolitan Area and elsewhere is, of course, an on-going process. Garda arrangements are continually under scrutiny to ensure that the police service provided is as effective as possible in all areas.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Attacks on Elderly Persons.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P. Gallagher Mr. P. Gallagher
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he is aware of the recent attacks on elderly persons living in isolated areas of County Donegal; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. McGinley Mr. McGinley
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he will take urgent action to halt the spate of attacks on elderly people in isolated areas and particularly in County Donegal.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): I propose to take Questions Nos. 425 and 426 together. I am aware of the attacks which have been taking place on the homes of elderly people in County Donegal in recent months, one of which resulted in a man's death. Unfortunately, there have been somewhat similar attacks in some other areas as well — one of which has resulted in the death of a woman — and it would be unrealistic to respond to these questions by reference only to County Donegal.
The seriousness of those developments does not need to be underlined, nor does the fact that they affect the well-being of many more people than have been the object of attack.

MainHeading.P: I am informed by the Garda authorities that two Garda centres have been set up to deal specifically with the type of attacks referred to in these questions. A detective inspector from the Garda Technical Bureau is in charge at each centre assisted by a number of detectives from the bureau. One centre was set up in Sligo on 3 December to co-ordinate Garda activity in the north-west and the other centre was set up in Roscommon on 6 December.

Special Garda check points have been mounted in the north-western counties in an effort to pinpoint the movement of vehicles likely to have been used in the perpetration of attacks. The local Gardaí have instructions to pay particular attention to the homes of elderly people during the course of their patrols and to call to advise them on matters of security, in particular against the dangers of keeping large sums of money in their homes.

As Deputies will be aware, a person was convicted and sentenced some time ago in connection with the death in County Donegal and a person has been charged in connection with the very recent death in County Roscommon. In addition, detections have been made in relation to several other attacks in County Donegal.

The Garda have mounted a publicity campaign locally and have involved local community groups in an effort to make people more security conscious and to report the movements of suspicious persons and vehicles. The Garda report a good response to those efforts.

I would add that, in relation to all the affected areas, the general response of a number of organisations, including community groups, has been very positive and helpful and that, with such an approach from them as well as from the Garda Síochána, there is every reason for confidence that the problem will be met.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Newspaper Extradition Reports.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kirk Mr. Kirk
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he is aware of a report in a British newspaper (details supplied) stating that on 7 and 8 November British security officials were in Dundalk looking for an individual suspected of criminal activities in Britain; that one of these officials informed the Garda authorities of the exact whereabouts of the individual involved; if so, if he will take urgent steps to ensure that the basic human rights of citizens are adequately safeguarded and proper legal procedures strictly adhered to; and if he will make a full statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): I have seen the report in question, as well as other associated material elsewhere in the same issue of the newspaper.

I am informed by the Garda authorities that they have no evidence that would substantiate in any way the allegation in the report that two British security officials were in Dundalk on 7 and 8 November “looking for” a particular person. I am also informed that the only British personnel who had any contact with the Garda Síochána at the relevant time about the case were two British police officers who were in Dublin in the first half of that week — up to Wednesday, 7 November — on official business in connection with the relevant warrants, which they had brought with them. Discussions between the two sides about warrants are confidential but, in any event, it will be clear from what I have said that the discussions in question took place either entirely or mainly before the period referred to in the newspaper article, not after it as would be implied by the article if it were to be taken as referring to those officers.

MainHeading.P: It may be noted that the British Embassy have issued an official statement denying that any British personnel were involved in Dundalk as alleged in the newspaper article. That statement also indicated that the only British personnel who had come here in connection with the case were the two British police officers who had come to deliver the warrants and then went on to Northern Ireland.

In view of what I have said, the issues relating to rights and procedures that are referred to in the second part of the question do not really arise but, since the matter has been mentioned, I would refer the Deputy to my reply to a Private Notice Question on 13 November (Official Report, Volume 353, column 1700) which related to the same case. In the course of that reply I took care to draw particular attention to the fact that fundamental legal requirements must not be ignored or overlooked and that rights must be respected.

Speaker.hpid: Miss Flaherty Miss Flaherty
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he will include in the Estimates for his Department a separate provision for the neighbourhood watch scheme.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): The cost of Garda services provided as part of the neighbourhood watch scheme is met from the overall financial allocation in the Garda Síochána Vote. There is in fact little or no additional direct cost involved for the Garda Síochána — there may be a small indirect cost on information leaflets etc. next year — and a separate provision in the Estimates would not be warranted or in accordance with normal practice relating to the presentation of the Estimates.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Dismissal of Former Superintendent.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Prendergast Mr. Prendergast
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he will examine the case of a person (details supplied) a former superintendent of the Garda Síochána who contends that: (a) he was dismissed from the force without an opportunity to clear his name; (b) that the grounds on which he was dismissed are without foundation; (c) that all the indications available suggest that he was the victim of a frame-up or a terrible mistake; (d) that there is no real evidence against him and as such, his dismissal is an apparent violation of equity and natural justice; (e) that he has sought without success for nearly 60 years to clear his name; (f) that a person (details supplied) who is a former chief superintendent, stated prior to his death that he was convinced of his innocence and if he will, for all the above reasons, make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): The dismissal of the former superintendent concerned, which took place in 1928, was very fully considered some years ago — in 1977-1978 to be precise — as a result of representations made to the then Minister for Justice by the man concerned. The outcome, however, was that no evidence could be found that would enable the Minister to be of any assistance in the matter.

What has been said in the course of the latest representations does not include anything of a substantial nature that is new. The reference in the text of the question to a favourable statement by a former chief superintendent is, I am afraid, incomplete. Whatever was said by the former chief superintendent in a favourable sense was subsequently withdrawn by him on the stated basis that the earlier comment was made only because he had been pestered, and the effect of his statements, taken together, was hardly supportive.

MainHeading.P: The only official record about the dismissal is the record of the decision to dismiss — there is no official documentation available as to the background. Whether the background information was ever recorded is not clear. Relevant papers, if they existed, would have been liable to have long since been pulped. Every effort was made to get information about the circumstances of the dismissal and all the material that was available, including press-cutting etc., was considered by the then Attorney General as well as by the Minister for Justice. The result of all the inquiries was that there was no adequate basis for rescinding the dismissal.

The then Minister wrote to the man concerned on 31 May 1978, to give the result of his inquiries and to explain, in detail, why no action was possible. He explained that it was not open to him to decide that a dismissal of some 50 years earlier was unjustified or even open to doubt because the information on which the authorities of that time acted was not still available to be evaluated — that, otherwise, numerous past decisions no matter how well justified would have to be rescinded because the evidence on which they were based had, in the normal process, been lost through the periodic pulping of old papers. The Minister mentioned the steps he had taken to get information and gave the results of those inquiries. The clear intention was that the recipient was to feel free to publish the Minister's letter if he thought it helpful to himself to do so.

In the absence of evidence that would substantiate the former superintendent's contentions I regret that I am not in a position to advance the matter further. As was said by my predecessor, it is a situation where those who know the man concerned or have read the evidence will make up their own minds.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Provision of Garda Station in Galway.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Coogan Mr. Coogan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he now recognises the need for a Garda station on the east side of Galway city in view of its rapidly growing population; and if he will give a commitment to the establishment of a Garda station on the east side in view of the fact that the new station on the west side of Galway is almost complete.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): The new Garda station to which the Deputy refers is being provided to replace the existing station at Eglington Street which is no longer adequate to meet Garda accommodation requirements. I am informed that the transfer of gardaí to this new station will not result in any reduction in the police service which is already being provided for the east side of the city.

With regard to the question of providing a Garda station on the east side of Galway city, I do not accept that the provision of an extra Garda station is necessarily the best way to improve Garda service to an area. The manning of an extra station tends to absorb considerable Garda manpower resources which might be better employed on outdoor patrolling in the area. I am informed by the Garda authorities that the police service for this part of the city has in fact been improved recently by the deployment of a Garda full time in the Mervue and Ballybane areas. The question of providing a new Garda station in this area will be kept under review.
